title: Local highways of South Korea
text:
In <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>, highways that are managed by the <a href="Provinces%20of%20South%20Korea">provincial governments</a> are called Local highways (). Usually route numbers have 2~4 digits; the first digit stands for the main province of its manager.
State-funded local highways.
There are some 2-digits local highways, called State-funded local highways (; short term of ). These highways are basically managed by province level, but its routes are designated and controlled by the South Korean government. Also, most of 2-digits Local highways stand for planned extension route of the same-number <a href="National%20highways%20of%20South%20Korea">national highways</a> or candidates for upgrading to national routes.
List of the routes.
These are the list of the routes. For the state-funded local highway, See <a href="%23State-funded%20local%20highways">#State-funded local highways</a>.
Gyeonggi Province (300s).
A lot of Local highways of <a href="Gyeonggi%20Province">Gyeonggi Province</a> were changed in 1996 and 2005.
